latest news.eng_title: EU's Borrell Criticizes Lack of Will to Influence Israel on Gaza Offensive
latest news.summary: The European Union's High Representative for Foreign Policy, Josep Borrell, has criticized the lack of political will from the European Union and the United States to influence Israel to stop its offensive in Gaza, which has left 40,265 dead in the past ten months. 'We have the capacity to influence Israel, of course we do', Borrell said, 'but what we lack is the will to influence'. He pointed out that in the past, Washington has acted to stop military aid and financial support to Israel, citing the 1982 Lebanon War and the pressure on Israeli authorities to attend the Madrid Peace Conference in 1991. Borrell noted that many of Israel's commercial exports go to the EU, and that the bloc has a policy of visa liberalization for Israeli citizens and supplies arms to Israel, just like the United States. According to Borrell, 'everyone reacts to effective pressure', and he lamented the lack of action from the US and EU, which have only denounced the high number of deaths. 'There will be a few more too many dead soon', he said. 'Do they want to use their influence or not? It seems they don't. There comes a time when diplomatic pressure is not enough and the phrase 'there are too many dead' becomes a phrase that alleviates your conscience but doesn't change anything', he added. Borrell also expressed skepticism about the progress of negotiations for a ceasefire. 'Every day without a ceasefire means more too many dead', he said. These comments come after Borrell confirmed that he will put on the table of EU member states the option of approving sanctions against members of the Israeli government for their support of radical settler attacks on Palestinian civilians in the West Bank, following the latest attack in the town of Jit that left one dead. The sanctions will be discussed at the informal meeting of EU foreign ministers next week in Brussels, with a focus on the Israeli Minister of Finance, Bezalel Smotrich, and the Minister of National Security, Itamar Ben Gvir, who have clashed with EU diplomacy over their 'incendiary' statements against the Palestinian population.
latest news.title: Borrell critica falta de voluntad de la UE y EEUU para pararle los pies a Israel en Gaza Infobae

latest news.eng_title: The Flames of War in the Region: A Threat to Turkey
latest news.summary: The world is waiting for Iran and Hezbollah's response to Israel's assassination of Fuad Şükr and İsmail Haniye in Beirut and Tehran. Meanwhile, in Gaza, a series of inhumane actions have taken place over the past week. Despite the importance of analyzing the events and the background, the media is filled with claims that Iran and Israel are engaging in a 'danışıklı dövüş' (a staged fight). In reality, the US and its Western allies have always used two methods in the region: bribery and threats. They bribe officials, media, and businesspeople in countries that are on their side, and threaten those who are not. The US has sent a massive naval fleet, including a nuclear-capable submarine, to the region. The US, along with NATO's five core countries (US, UK, France, Germany, and Italy), issued a joint statement warning Iran not to escalate tensions in the region and promising to defend Israel if it is attacked. However, this was not a warning, but a threat that disregards international law and the sovereignty of nations. Iran's Foreign Minister Kenani responded to this threat by stating that Iran will defend itself without seeking permission from anyone. The leader of the Yemeni Ansarullah Movement, el-Husi, said that the US's attempt to prevent the resistance's response has failed and that the US's massive military presence in the region will not deter the resistance's determination to fight against Israel. The US is also trying to revive the ceasefire talks in Qatar. However, the resistance has stated that it will only stop its operations if the war in Gaza is stopped. Iran and Hezbollah have stated that they will respond to the assassination of Fuad Şükr and İsmail Haniye, but not to the war in Gaza. The US is following the Doha talks closely, with CIA Director William Burns and diplomat Brett McGurk attending the talks. However, Hamas has not taken the talks seriously, with its Political Bureau member Usame Hamdan stating that Hamas will only participate in the talks if the Biden plan is implemented. The leader of the Gaza resistance, Yahya Sinvar, has refused to participate in the talks, stating that Netanyahu does not want the war to end. The talks have been unsuccessful so far, and the next round is scheduled for this week. In Turkey, President Erdoğan has stated that Turkey will take the same steps as it did in Karabakh and Libya if necessary. Israeli Foreign Minister Katz has responded by threatening Erdoğan, saying that he is following in the footsteps of Saddam Hussein. Azeri media has praised the Azeri army and people for their victory in Karabakh, and stated that the military aid sent by Turkey was not a help, but a payment for the aid. Meanwhile, the leader of the main opposition party is on a tour of Palestine, visiting sites such as the Al-Aqsa Mosque and the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. The Israeli aim is to capture the Arz-ı Mev'ud. The current conflict is not a Hamas-Israel war, but a larger conflict that involves the entire region. Turkey should be aware that the flames of war in the region will eventually reach its doorstep.
latest news.title: Fitiller ateşlendi

latest news.eng_title: Israel Denies Considering International Force in Gaza-Egypt Border
latest news.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu denied reports that Israel is considering the deployment of an international force along the narrow border strip between Gaza and Egypt known as the Philadelphi Corridor. According to his office, Netanyahu 'insists on the principle that Israel will control the Philadelphi Corridor to prevent Hamas from rearming, which would allow them to repeat the atrocities of October 7'. This statement emphasizes Israel's commitment to maintaining control over the corridor.
latest news.title: Israel niega que esté considerando aceptar una fuerza internacional en frontera entre egipto y gaza

latest news.eng_title: Israel denies it's considering accepting international force on Egypt-Gaza border
latest news.summary: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu denied reports that the country is considering deploying an international force along the Philadelphi Corridor, a narrow border strip between Gaza and Egypt. According to Netanyahu's office, he insists that Israel must control the corridor to prevent Hamas from rearming and repeating the atrocities of October 7. Netanyahu's statement emphasizes the importance of Israel maintaining control over the corridor to prevent Hamas from posing a threat.
latest news.title: Israel denies it's considering accepting international force on Egypt-Gaza border

latest news.eng_title: Iraq and Saudi Arabia Call for International Action to Stop Israeli Attack on Gaza
latest news.summary: Iraq and Saudi Arabia have urged the international community to take action to prevent the ongoing Israeli attack on Gaza. Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia' Al-Sudani emphasized the need for continued cooperation and coordination between Arab and international efforts to stop the Israeli aggression on Gaza. The two countries discussed their bilateral relations and ways to develop and strengthen them, particularly in the fields of politics and economy. The Israeli military operations in Gaza have been ongoing since October 7, 2023, resulting in over 40,000 deaths and more than 92,000 injuries. New rounds of negotiations began in Doha on Wednesday, mediated by the US, Qatar, and Egypt, to discuss a prisoner exchange deal in Gaza. However, Hamas has refused to participate, citing its demands and stating that it had previously agreed to the proposed terms and would not return to negotiations to give Netanyahu more time.
latest news.title: العراق والسعودية تؤكدان ضرورة تنسيق الجهود العربية والدولية لإيقاف الهجوم الإسرائيلي على غزة

latest news.eng_title: Netanyahu Refuses to Back Down on Gaza Corridor, Stalling Peace Talks
latest news.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu has not changed his position on maintaining control over the military corridor in Gaza, the Philadelphia Corridor, according to a diplomatic source cited by the Times of Israel. This contradicts statements made by US officials to the Washington Post that Netanyahu had offered concessions on the issue in a phone call with President Joe Biden the previous day. Israel will not accept the withdrawal of Israeli military forces from the Philadelphia Corridor, confirming that this was the real sticking point in the Gaza negotiations, not the prisoner exchange. Hamas had demanded the complete withdrawal of Israeli forces from the Gaza Strip, including the Philadelphia Corridor, as a condition for reaching an agreement with Israel on a ceasefire in Gaza. Yesterday evening, Netanyahu's office denied previous media reports, stating in a statement: 'Israel will insist on achieving all its war objectives, as defined by the security cabinet, including ensuring that Gaza will never again pose a threat to Israel's security. This requires securing the southern border.' A source had reported to the US news portal Axios that President Biden had had a phone call with Netanyahu to encourage him to show more flexibility in order to reach an agreement for the release of hostages and a ceasefire in Gaza. According to Axios, the conversation focused on Netanyahu's new request that Israeli forces remain deployed along the Philadelphia Corridor. Israeli negotiators and US officials have stated that this new request represents a significant obstacle to a possible agreement. Meanwhile, the Resistance Axis continues to attack Israeli and international targets from Lebanon and the Red Sea. Air raid sirens sounded in the northern Israeli city of Kiryat Shmona and surrounding communities of Tel Hai and Kfar Yuval this morning. A tanker ship, the Sounion, was hit by Houthi raids in the Red Sea, according to the EU's Operation Aspides. However, it is unclear if the ship is still on fire. A French warship has rescued the 29 crew members of the tanker. The ship, bound for the Israeli port of Eilat, reported being approached for the first time by two small boats with around 15 people on board and reported a brief exchange of gunfire during the incident 77 nautical miles (142 km) west of the Yemeni port of Hodeidah, said the UKMTO, the British naval agency.
latest news.title: Netanyahu non cede sui corridoi militari a Gaza. Negoziati inutili. Colpita nave diretta in Israele

latest news.eng_title: US Efforts to Broker Ceasefire Between Israel and Hamas Face Challenges
latest news.summary: It is unlikely that the Biden administration will succeed in reconciling Israel and Hamas, as it may be the only party interested in a ceasefire at this stage. The administration is trying to leave a legacy for President Biden, who has made significant efforts to end the conflict in Gaza, at least, over the past ten months. However, it has failed to achieve this goal. The administration has recently put its weight behind new proposals for a ceasefire agreement, amid efforts to avoid an Israeli-Iranian war that would require US involvement. Pentagon spokesperson Pat Ryder said, 'Our focus is on de-escalating the situation, and we have placed additional military capabilities in the region to enable us to defend our forces and also support the defense of Israel when it is attacked. We are trying to deter a large-scale regional conflict and prevent a regional war in the Middle East, which is already tense.' The US and Israel have a shared security relationship...
latest news.title: وقف النار: مصلحة أميركية فحسب!

latest news.eng_title: Netanyahu: Israel will not remove troops from Gaza border
latest news.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has refused to remove troops from the Philadelphi corridor, a border area between Egypt and Gaza, according to Reuters. This decision has been a point of contention in the US-led efforts to reach a ceasefire agreement and release hostages. A Norwegian news source reported that Netanyahu had agreed to remove the troops, but this was later found to be incorrect. Netanyahu's position on this issue has been a challenge in the peace process.
latest news.title: Netanyahu: Israel vil ikke fjerne styrker på grensen til Egypt

latest news.eng_title: Israeli PM states troops will not leave Philadelphi Corridor in Gaza
latest news.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office denied a report that Israel had agreed to withdraw its troops from the Philadelphi Corridor in Gaza. According to Netanyahu's office, 'Israel will insist on the achievement of all of its objectives for the war, as they have been defined by the Security Cabinet, including that Gaza never again constitutes a security threat to Israel. This requires securing the southern border.' This statement suggests that Israel has no intention of leaving the Philadelphi Corridor. The Philadelphi Corridor is a border region between Egypt and Gaza that has been a point of contention in the conflict. Netanyahu's office stated that securing the southern border is a key objective of the war.
latest news.title: Israeli PM states troops will not leave Philadelphi Corridor in Gaza

latest news.eng_title: Middle East saber-rattling could fuel global polycrisis
latest news.summary: The Middle East is a potential trigger for a global polycrisis, with the Gaza conflict escalating into a larger war between Israel and Iran. U.S. National Security Council spokesman John Kirby warned that Iran could carry out retaliatory military measures on Israel soon, stating 'we have to be prepared for what could be a significant set of attacks.' Iran has been expected to launch a bigger strike after attacking Israel in April with 300 missiles and drones. Despite calls for restraint from European leaders, including UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, French President Emmanuel Macron, and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, the situation remains volatile, with the U.S. military building up assets in the region. A long-sought Israel-Hamas ceasefire is increasingly uncertain, and the possibility of a larger conflict is growing.
latest news.title: Middle East saber-rattling could fuel global polycrisis

news knowledge.eng_title: Diplomatic Efforts to Prevent War Between Iran and Israel
news knowledge.summary: Recent diplomatic efforts have attempted to prevent a full-scale war between Iran, Israel, and their allies. The negotiations, led by the US, Qatar, and Egypt, have been ongoing since August 15. The US has proposed a plan to help resolve the conflict, which includes a ceasefire in Gaza, the release of Palestinian prisoners, and a significant prisoner exchange. However, Hamas has rejected the proposal, citing concerns about the presence of Israeli troops on the Gaza-Egypt border and the conditions for the release of its members from Israeli prisons. The US has also been working on a parallel plan, which includes a potential attack on Iran if negotiations fail. Meanwhile, France and the UK have been involved in separate diplomatic efforts, with the French foreign minister visiting Lebanon and the British foreign minister visiting Israel. The situation remains tense, with both sides waiting for the other to make a move. According to Israeli officials, the Iranian military has reduced its readiness for a potential attack, but the situation can change quickly. The next few days will be crucial in determining the outcome of the negotiations and the potential for a conflict.
news knowledge.title: Переговоры в Катаре: Предотвратит ли дипломатия войну между Ираном и Израилем

news knowledge.eng_title: UK and France Call for Diplomatic Solution to Gaza Crisis
news knowledge.summary: The UK and France have called for a diplomatic solution to achieve a ceasefire in Gaza and restore peace along the Israeli-Lebanese border. The two countries' foreign ministers, David Laming and Stéphane Séguin, visited Israel and the Palestinian territories together, aiming to urge an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and reduce tensions. The visit marked the first joint visit by the UK and France to Israel in over a decade. A joint statement released after the visit read: 'We, the French and British foreign ministers, share a common interest in the security of the State of Israel and stability in the region as a whole. As permanent members of the UN Security Council, we have a specific responsibility to support the current escalation and ensure a lasting peace for Israelis, Palestinians, and the region as a whole.' The statement emphasized the need to reduce tensions in the region, and urged Iran and its allies to retract their ongoing threats to launch a military attack against Israel. The ministers also stressed the importance of ending the cycle of revenge and retaliation, and reiterated their commitment to the full implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 1701 on Lebanon. They expressed their full support for the current efforts to reach a ceasefire agreement and the release of hostages in Gaza, led by the US, Egypt, and Qatar. The statement concluded by emphasizing the need for all parties to fulfill their responsibilities, and for the urgent delivery and distribution of humanitarian aid without restrictions, as well as the protection of civilians. The ministers reaffirmed that only a two-state solution, in accordance with international law, can bring lasting peace to both Israelis and Palestinians. They strongly condemned the violence of settlers in the West Bank, which threatens both Israeli and Palestinian security and can jeopardize ongoing diplomatic efforts. The statement concluded by reaffirming the UK and France's commitment to supporting cooperation and normalization in the region, and urged all parties to take concrete steps to avoid war. 'We are ready to engage with them to achieve this goal,' the statement said.
news knowledge.title: بريطانيا وفرنسا: خفض التوتر في الشرق الأوسط

news knowledge.eng_title: Israel-Hamas Conflict: Diplomatic Efforts for a Truce Amid Escalating Tensions
news knowledge.summary: British and French foreign ministers visited Israel on August 16 to call for a de-escalation in the region, as Hezbollah and Iran threatened to retaliate after the assassination of the Hamas leader and the Hezbollah military chief. Meanwhile, negotiations for a truce in Gaza continued in Cairo. Israeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz stated that he expects his allies to 'join Israel' in attacking Iran if the Islamic Republic attacks Israel, according to a statement from his office. 'Israel expects France and the UK to clearly and publicly tell Iran that it is forbidden to attack Israel, and that if Iran attacks, the coalition led by the US will join Israel not only to defend it but also to attack important targets in Iran,' he said, according to a statement from his office. French Foreign Minister Stéphane Séjourné disagreed, saying it was 'inconvenient to talk about Israeli retaliation, even defensive, while we are working towards a diplomatic agreement.' The US presented a revised proposal for a ceasefire in Gaza on August 16, but the Hamas immediately rejected 'new conditions' from Israel, as diplomatic pressure intensifies to avoid a regional military escalation. Mediators - the US, Qatar, and Egypt - announced the resumption of talks next week in Cairo, after presenting a new compromise in Doha to implement an agreement on a ceasefire. An agreement has 'never been so close,' US President Joe Biden assured. Several Israeli politicians condemned the deadly attack in the West Bank by dozens of Israeli settlers. The attack occurred near the city of Kalkiliya, killing at least one person on Thursday evening. 'Violent settler attacks against Palestinian civilians in the West Bank are unacceptable and must stop,' said a spokesperson for the National Security Council, urging Israeli authorities to take necessary measures to 'protect all communities.' The European Union's foreign chief, Josep Borrell, said he wants to 'submit a proposal for EU sanctions against accomplices of violent settlers, including some Israeli government members.' The UN described the attack as 'horrible,' adding that 'overall, we are witnessing impunity' for such acts. The Gaza Health Ministry announced the first confirmed case of polio in Gaza, which has been polio-free for 25 years. The case involves a 10-month-old baby who had not been vaccinated in Deir Al-Balah. Two UN agencies have requested 'humanitarian pauses' in the fighting in Gaza to vaccinate over 640,000 children under 10 against polio in the coming weeks.
news knowledge.title: Guerre Israël-Hamas : négociations pour une trêve, vaccin, Iran... Les dernières infos

news knowledge.eng_title: French and British Foreign Ministers to Visit Israel to Address Regional Escalation
news knowledge.summary: The foreign ministers of France and the UK, Stéphane Séjourné and David Lammy, will visit Israel on Friday to discuss with their Israeli counterpart, Israel Katz, 'efforts to avoid a regional escalation'. According to the Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 'Minister Katz will meet with the Foreign Ministers of the UK and France tomorrow to discuss efforts to avoid a regional escalation.' The meeting is expected to focus on promoting 'severe economic sanctions against Iran in relation to the nuclear issue, missiles, and unmanned aerial vehicles, and the declaration of the Revolutionary Guard as a terrorist organization.' Additionally, the tripartite meeting is expected to promote an agreement for the release of the Israeli hostages held in the Gaza Strip by Hamas. Meanwhile, a delegation from Israel has arrived in Doha to resume negotiations with mediators (US, Egypt, and Qatar) for a ceasefire in the enclave, which would allow for the release of the hostages. However, Hamas has announced that it will not attend the meeting, citing Iran's threat to attack Israel in retaliation for the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran two weeks ago, as well as the killing of Hizbulá's military leader Fuad Shukr by Israel. Despite this, the international community is exhausting all diplomatic channels to achieve an agreement in the Gaza Strip that would dissuade Iran and its allies, and even the US has stated that Hamas has agreed to maintain contact with the mediators after the meeting.
news knowledge.title: Ministros de Exteriores de Francia y Reino Unido visitarán Israel para abordar escalada

news knowledge.eng_title: European Countries Urge Iran to Avoid Retaliation Against Israel
news knowledge.summary: European countries are in intense communication with Iran to persuade it not to retaliate against Israel after the assassination of Hamas' former political bureau chief Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran. Meanwhile, French, German, Italian, and British leaders issued a joint statement calling for a ceasefire in Gaza. German Chancellor Frank-Walter Steinmeier spoke with Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi on Monday, discussing the recent escalation in the region and ways to contain it, as well as bilateral relations between the two countries. Raisi emphasized that Iran welcomes expanding cooperation with all countries and believes in resolving issues through diplomacy, but will not give in to pressure, sanctions, arrogance, and aggression. Steinmeier stressed the importance of strengthening relations in various fields, highlighting the need for stability in the region, a halt to war and violence in Gaza, and calling for a ceasefire. The Vatican also called for avoiding the spread of conflict. Cardinal Pietro Parolin, the Vatican's Secretary of State, called for dialogue to prevent escalation in the Middle East. He expressed concern about the situation in the region and emphasized the need for all parties to work towards a peaceful resolution. The US, UK, France, Germany, and Italy issued a joint statement calling for a ceasefire in Gaza, urging Iran to stop threatening Israel with a military attack. The statement emphasized that such an attack would have severe consequences for regional security. The US has approved $3.5 billion in military aid to Israel, despite calls for a ceasefire in Gaza. Since October 7, 2023, Israel has been waging a devastating war on Gaza, killing over 131,000 people, mostly children and women, and injuring over 10,000, with many more missing.
news knowledge.title: اتصالات أوروبية مع طهران لثنيها عن الرد على تل أبيب.. وبيان غربي مشترك يدعو لوقف إطلاق النار بغزة

news knowledge.eng_title: France, Germany, and UK Warn Iran Against Attacking Israel
news knowledge.summary: France, Germany, and the UK have issued a warning to Iran not to attack Israel, following the recent assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran. The three countries stated that any retaliation would undermine peace negotiations and called on Iran and its allies to refrain from extreme actions. The statement read, 'We call on Iran and its allies to refrain from attacks that could further intensify regional tensions and jeopardize the opportunity to agree on a ceasefire and the release of hostages.' The importance of ending the ongoing conflict in Gaza, which has lasted over a year, was also emphasized. Despite the allied nations' support for Israel, the Israeli military has already implemented strategies to protect its borders from potential Iranian attacks. Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant stated that they are preparing for any attack and have already met with the Foreign Affairs and Security Committee of the Knesset (Israeli Parliament) to discuss their readiness. However, Iran has stated that it will only return to peace agreements if mediators focus on a plan based on previous dialogues, leaving the future of diplomatic sessions uncertain.
news knowledge.title: Francia, Alemania y Reino Unido lanzan advertencia a Irán para que no ataque a Israel

news knowledge.eng_title: International Pressure Mounts to Avoid War Between Iran and Israel
news knowledge.summary: The international diplomatic pressure is increasing to avoid a war between Iran and Israel. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned the G7 that an attack by Tehran and Hezbollah on Israel could happen in the next 24 hours. According to three anonymous sources cited by Axios, Blinken explained in a virtual meeting with allies that 'for the US, Iran and Hezbollah will both react', but Washington 'does not know the exact moment of the attacks' or their form. The US hopes to stop the escalation by convincing Iran and Hezbollah to limit their attacks and restrain any Israeli response, and Blinken 'asked other foreign ministers to join this push by pressuring the three'. While President Joe Biden saw the national security team and spoke with Jordan's King Abdullah II, the G7 foreign ministers, after Sunday's meeting, 'expressed deep concern for the rising level of tension in the Middle East, which threatens to trigger a wider conflict in the region'. In a joint statement, they launched an 'appeal to all parties to moderation and to engage in a constructive way for de-escalation', as also stated by the US State Department spokesperson, Matthew Miller. 'No country or nation has anything to gain from further escalation', the foreign ministers of Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, the UK, and the US, along with the EU's High Representative, stated. Italian Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani also reiterated on X that 'we are working for a ceasefire in Gaza, the release of hostages, and intensified humanitarian engagement in the Strip. We will do our best to achieve peace'. Meanwhile, Israel has confirmed Blinken's information that the attack by Tehran could start within the next 24 hours, but from Jerusalem, they believe it is impossible to predict it with precision. Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant, after warning that 'if they dare to attack us, they will pay a high price', spoke with Pentagon Chief Lloyd Austin to inform him 'on the developments of security in the region and on the readiness of the Idf to defend Israel from potential threats posed by Iran and its delegates'. Gallant 'discussed a series of scenarios and the corresponding defensive and offensive capabilities', his office reported, adding that the minister 'expressed his appreciation to Austin for the close military and strategic coordination with the US, including the current and future deployment of military capabilities and the changes in the defense force position in Israel'. He also emphasized 'the importance of US leadership in forming a coalition of allies and partners to defend Tel Aviv and the region from a series of aerial attacks'. After the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh on July 31, Washington sent additional military forces to the Middle East in anticipation of reprisals, insisting that it is a 'defensive deployment'. Italian Defense Minister Guido Crosetto also spoke with Gallant, highlighting on X that 'Italy continues to work to promote dialogue, reduce tension, and avoid a grave and dangerous escalation'. Yesterday, as reported by the Israeli military, 'the head of the US Central Command, General Michael Erik Kurilla, arrived in the country' and met with the Chief of Staff, Lieutenant General Herzi Halevi: the two 'held a joint assessment of the situation on strategic and security issues'.
news knowledge.title: Il pressing internazionale per evitare la guerra totale

news knowledge.eng_title: Diplomatic Maneuvers to Avoid Military Escalation in the Middle East
news knowledge.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has stated that his country is prepared to face Iran and its allies on all fronts. 'Anyone who kills our citizens or harms our country (...) will pay a very high price,' he warned on Sunday evening. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Volker Türk, has urged all parties, as well as countries with influence, to act urgently to avoid a wider conflict in the region. Iran, the Palestinian Islamist movement Hamas, and the Lebanese Hezbollah have accused Israel of the death of Hamas leader Ismaïl Haniyeh, killed in his residence in Tehran on Wednesday. Israel has not commented on Haniyeh's death, but had vowed to destroy Hamas after the unprecedented attack by the movement on its soil on October 7, which triggered the devastating war in Gaza. 'Israel has crossed red lines,' said Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah, while Iran's Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei threatened a severe punishment. The US, Israel's main ally, has strengthened its military presence in the Middle East while seeking to diplomatically de-escalate the situation. 'We are determined to oppose Iran and its allies on all fronts, in all arenas,' Netanyahu said at a ceremony in Jerusalem. The US, Sweden, the UK, France, Jordan, and Saudi Arabia have called on their citizens to leave Lebanon, while several airlines have suspended flights to Beirut, including Lufthansa, Air France, and Transavia. The situation remains tense, with daily exchanges of fire at the Israeli-Lebanese border and Israeli airstrikes on the south of Lebanon, which have killed four people, according to Lebanese authorities and Hezbollah. 'We can't know what will happen in 20 minutes (...) But we are a strong country and I think we will win this war,' said Yehuda Levi, a shop owner in Haifa. '39,623 dead in Gaza according to Hamas' - The situation is critical, with many countries urging their citizens to leave the region.
news knowledge.title: Manœuvres diplomatiques pour éviter une escalade militaire au Moyen-Orient

news knowledge.eng_title: France and US Urge Maximum Restraint in Middle East
news knowledge.summary: The French and US diplomatic chiefs agreed to urge all parties in the Middle East to 'exercise maximum restraint' to avoid a regional conflict, according to the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Stéphane Séjourné spoke with Antony Blinken and shared 'their concerns about the increasing tensions' in the region, said Christophe Lemoine, the ministry's spokesperson. 'They agreed to continue to urge all parties to exercise maximum restraint, in order to avoid any regional conflagration that would have devastating consequences for the countries in the region,' he added. The two countries will also continue joint efforts for a 'sustainable' ceasefire in Gaza. This meeting took place at a time when concerns about a possible military escalation in the Middle East have increased due to the amplification of threats against Israel by Iran and its allies. Iran, the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas, and its Lebanese ally Hezbollah blamed Israel for the death in Tehran on Wednesday of the Palestinian movement's leader, Ismail Haniyeh. The assassination occurred just hours after an attack claimed by Israel killed the military chief of the Lebanese movement, Fouad Chokr, near Beirut on Tuesday night. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said his country is at a 'very high level' of preparation for any scenario, 'both defensive and offensive.' On Friday, Paris asked French visitors still in Iran to leave the country 'as quickly as possible.' In the case of Lebanon, France did not explicitly ask its citizens to leave the country, unlike Washington and London. However, in its updated travel advice on Thursday, the ministry warned French citizens, particularly those passing through, that commercial flights to France are still available. Since the Gaza war, France has formally recommended that French citizens 'except for imperative reasons, not travel to Lebanon, including for tourism and family visits.'
news knowledge.title: Paris e Washington pedem "máxima contenção" no Médio Oriente

news knowledge.eng_title: UK Foreign Secretary David Lammy: Britain seeks balanced stance on Israeli-Palestinian conflict
news knowledge.summary: British Foreign Secretary David Lammy said in an interview with Reuters that his country wants to take a balanced stance towards the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and will use diplomatic efforts to achieve a ceasefire and the release of Palestinian prisoners held by Hamas. Lammy is currently visiting Germany, his first foreign trip since the Labor Party's landslide victory in the British elections on Friday, which ended 14 years of Conservative rule and brought Keir Starmer to the position of Prime Minister. Lammy said, 'It's time for the United Kingdom to reconnect with the outside world.' He added, 'I want to return to taking a balanced stance on Israel and Gaza. We have made it clear that we want to see a ceasefire... We want the release of these prisoners.' He also stated, 'The fighting must stop, and humanitarian aid must be allowed in. I will use all diplomatic efforts to ensure a ceasefire.' Despite his party's landslide victory in the elections, the Labor Party suffered significant losses in areas with large Muslim populations due to their anger over the party's stance on the war in Gaza. The efforts to reach an agreement on a ceasefire and the release of prisoners in Gaza gained momentum on Friday after Hamas presented a modified proposal on the agreement terms, and Israel said the negotiations will continue this week. According to Gaza's health authorities, over 38,000 Palestinians have been killed in the Israeli military campaign on Gaza since October 7, 2023, in response to Hamas's attack on Israeli towns on the same day. Israeli statistics indicate that 1,200 people were killed and over 250 hostages were taken in Hamas's attack on Israel on October 7, 2023. Lammy said that Britain will seek to re-establish its global positions on some issues, including the climate crisis and major relationships, such as its relations with European powers and emerging powers. He added, 'Let's put Britain's exit from the European Union behind us... There are many things we can do together.' The British Foreign Office said that Lammy will travel to Poland and Sweden on Sunday, where he will focus on areas including cooperation in NATO and the war in Ukraine.
news knowledge.title: وزير خارجية بريطانيا يقول إن بلاده تسعى لموقف متوازن تجاه إسرائيل وغزة
